The sum of the weights of the ten students is 225 kg + 275 kg = <<225+275=500>>500 kg.

context: Bobby received his weekly paycheck today.  Although his salary is $450 per week, his actual paycheck is reduced in size because there are some taxes, insurance payments, and fees removed from his pay before his employer writes the check.
main-q: If the government removes 1/3 in federal taxes and 8% in state taxes, the health insurance removes $50 per week, the life insurance removes $20 per week, and the city charges him a fee of $10 per week for parking, then what is the final amount left in Bobby's paycheck, in dollars?
qa-pairs: How much does the federal government take out?
The federal government takes out 1/3*450=<<1/3*450=150>>150 dollars.
How much does the state take out?
The state takes out 0.08*450=<<0.08*450=36>>36 dollars.
What is the final amount left in Bobby's paycheck?
Then the final amount remaining after all the deductions are removed is 450-150-36-50-20-10=<<450-150-36-50-20-10=184>>184 dollars.

context: Colleen is making a batch of 48 cookies. She's going to add 108 chocolate chips and one-third as many M&Ms to the whole batch.
main-q: What are the average number of chocolate pieces in each cookie?
qa-pairs: How many M&Ms are there?
First find the total number of M&Ms: 108 chocolate chips / 3 chocolate chips / 1 M&M = <<108/3/1=36>>36 M&Ms.
How many chocolates are there?
Then add that number to the number of chocolate chips to find the total number of pieces of chocolate: 36 M&Ms + 108 chocolate chips = <<36+108=144>>144 chocolates.
How many chocolates are there per cookie?
Then divide the total number of chocolates by the number of cookies to find the number of pieces of chocolate per cookie: 144 chocolates / 48 cookies = <<144/48=3>>3 chocolates/cookie.

context: Rudy runs 5 miles at a rate of 10 minutes per mile. Later he runs 4 miles at a rate of 9.5 minutes per mile.
main-q: What is the total length of time that Rudy runs?
qa-pairs: How many minutes does Rudy run for?
Rudy first runs for 5 * 10 = <<5*10=50>>50 minutes.
How many minutes does Rudy run for?
Then Rudy runs for 4 * 9.5 = <<4*9.5=38>>38 minutes.
How long does Rudy run for?
Rudy runs for a total length of 50 + 38 = <<50+38=88>>88 minutes.

context: June liked to collect cat stickers.  She had a total of 76 in her collection.  Her twin sister Bonnie also collected cat stickers and had 63 in her collection.  For their birthday, their grandparents gave them 25 cat stickers each.
main-q: How many combined stickers did they have?
qa-pairs: How many stickers did June have?
June had 76 stickers and was given 25 from her grandparents so she had 76 + 25 = <<76+25=101>>101 stickers.
How many stickers did Bonnie have?
Bonnie had 63 stickers and was given 25 from her grandparents so she had 63 + 25 = <<63+25=88>>88 stickers.
How many combined stickers did they have?
June had 101 stickers and Bonnie had 88 stickers so together, they had 101 + 88 = <<101+88=189>>189 stickers.

context: 4 students participated in a 200m race.
main-q: If the average completion time of the last three students was 35 seconds, and the average completion time of all four runners was 30 seconds, how long (in seconds) did it take the student who came first to finish the race?
qa-pairs: How long did the last 3 students take to finish the race?
The last 3 students had an average completion time of 35 seconds so the sum of their completion times was 3*35 = <<3*35=105>>105 seconds.
How long did all 4 students take to finish the race?
All 4 students (now including the student who came first) had an average completion time of 30 seconds, meaning the sum of their completion times is 4*30 = <<4*30=120>>120 seconds.
How long did the student who came first take to finish the race?
The student who came first spent 120-105 = <<120-105=15>>15 seconds in the race.

main-q: f Katherine has 4 apples and 3 times as many pears in her fridge, how many bananas does she have if she has a total of 21 pieces of fruit?
qa-pairs: How many pears does Katherine have?
Katherine has a total of 3 * 4 apples = <<3*4=12>>12 pears.
How many apples and pears does Katherine have?
She therefore had 4 apples + 12 pears = <<4+12=16>>16 apples and pears.
How many bananas does Katherine have?
We know she has 21 total pieces of fruit, so this means she must have 21 total - 16 = <<21-16=5>>5 bananas.

context: Peter is raking leaves. It takes him 15 minutes to rake 3 bags of leaves.
main-q: If he keeps raking at the same rate, how long will it take him to rake 8 bags?
qa-pairs: How many bags of leaves can Peter rake in Y minutes?
We are trying to figure out how long it will take Peter to rake 8 bags of leaves, so we'll call that Y. And we know Peter can rake 3 bags of leaves / 15 minutes = 8 bags of leaves / Y.
How many minutes does it take Peter to rake 8 bags of leaves?
Next, we will multiply to find the cross-products. 3 x Y = 15 x 8 or 3Y = 120.
How many minutes does it take Peter to rake 8 bags of leaves?
We want to get figure out Y, so we need to get it by itself by dividing by 3, like this: 3Y/3 = 120/3 or Y = 40 minutes.

context: Jacoby wants to save money for a trip to Brickville. He needs to have $5000 total to go on his trip. He works a job earning $20 per hour and works 10 hours. He then finds he can sell cookies for $4 each, and he sells 24 pieces of cookies. With the money he has so far, he buys a lottery ticket for $10 and wins $500. Finally, he gets $500 from both of his sisters as a gift.
main-q: How much more, in dollars, does Jacob need to go to Brickville?
qa-pairs: How much does Jacob earn?
Jacob earns $20 per hour * 10 hours = $<<20*10=200>>200 for working.
How much does Jacob earn from selling cookies?
So he earns $4 each * 24 = $<<4*24=96>>96 for the cookies.
How much does Jacob have so far?

context: Sam bought a dozen boxes, each with 30 highlighter pens inside, for $10 each box. He rearranged five of these boxes into packages of six highlighters each and sold them for $3 per package. He sold the rest of the highlighters separately at the rate of three pens for $2.
main-q: How much profit did he make in total, in dollars?
qa-pairs: How much did Sam spend on highlighters?
Sam bought 12 boxes x $10 = $<<12*10=120>>120 worth of highlighters.
How many highlighters did Sam buy?
He bought 12 * 30 = <<12*30=360>>360 highlighters in total.
How many highlighters did Sam take?
Sam then took 5 boxes × 6 highlighters/box = <<5*6=30>>30 highlighters.

context: Mark plants some strawberries in his backyard. Every month, the number of strawberry plants doubles. After 3 months, Mark digs up 4 strawberry plants and gives them to his friend.
main-q: If he still has 20 strawberry plants, how many did he initially plant?
qa-pairs: How many plants did Mark give away?
First, add the 4 plants Mark gave away to the 20 he has left: 4 + 20 = <<4+20=24>>24.
How many plants did Mark have after two months?
Then divide this number by 2 to find how many plants Mark had after two months: 24 / 2 = <<24/2=12>>12.
How many plants did Mark have after one month?
Then divide that number by 2 to find how many plants Mark had after one month: 12 / 2 = <<6=6>>6.

context: Tom opens an amusement park.  It cost $100,000 to open initially.  It also cost 1% of that to run per day.  He sells 150  tickets a day for $10 each.
main-q: How long will it take to make back his money?
qa-pairs: How much does it cost to keep the place open?
It cost 100,000*.01=$<<100000*.01=1000>>1,000 a day to keep the place open.
How much does Tom make from the park?
He makes 150*10=$<<150*10=1500>>1500 a day from the park.
How much does Tom make in profit?
So he makes a profit of 1500-1000=$<<1500-1000=500>>500 a day.

context: Georgia is working on a math test with 75 problems on it. After 20 minutes she has completed 10 problems. After another 20 minutes, she has completed twice as many problems. She has 40 minutes to complete the rest of the test.
main-q: How many problems does she have left to solve?
qa-pairs: How many problems did Georgia complete?
Georgia's test started with 75 problems and then Georgia completed 10, 75 - 10 = <<75-10=65>>65 problems.
How many problems does Georgia complete after 20 minutes?
After 20 minutes she completes twice as many problems, 10 x 2 = <<10*2=20>>20.
How many problems does Georgia complete in 40 minutes?
With 40 minutes left she has completed 10 + 20 problems = <<10+20=30>>30 problems.

context: A baker sells pastries for $5 and works 7 days a week. On Monday he sold 2. Every day the number of sales increases by 1 compared to the previous day.
main-q: On average, how many pastries does he sell on each day of the week?
qa-pairs: How many pastries does the baker sell on each day of the week?
You know from the statement that on Monday he sells 2 pastries, so on Tuesday he sells 3, Wednesday 4, Thursday 5, Friday 6, Saturday 7 and Sunday 8 pastries.
How many pastries does the baker sell on each day of the week?
So the average value is (2+3+4+5+6+7+8) pastries/7 days.
How many pastries does the baker sell on each day of the week?
The baker sells, on average, 35/7= <<35/7=5>>5 pastries/day for 1 week.

context: Jessica is having a sweet tooth and bought 10 chocolate bars, 10 packs of gummy bears, and 20 bags of chocolate chips. Her total rang up to $150.
main-q: If the cost of a pack of gummy bears is $2 and a bag of chocolate chips costs $5, how much does 1 chocolate bar cost?
qa-pairs: How much do the gummy bears cost?
The gummy bears cost 10*2=$<<10*2=20>>20.
How much do the chocolate chips cost?
The chocolate chips cost 5*20=$<<5*20=100>>100.
How much do the gummy bears and chocolate chips cost together?
The total cost for these two is 100+20=$<<100+20=120>>120.

context: Jorge is 24 years younger than Simon. In 2005, Jorge is 16 years old.
main-q: In 2010, how old would Simon be?
qa-pairs: How old was Simon in 2005?
In 2005, Simon was 16+24 = <<16+24=40>>40 years old.
How many years are between 2005 and 2010?
In 2010, how old would Simon be?
In 2010 Simon would be 40+5 = 45 years old.

context: Chad bought 6 packages of cat food and 2 packages of dog food. Each package of cat food contained 9 cans, and each package of dog food contained 3 cans.
main-q: How many more cans of cat food than dog food did Chad buy?
qa-pairs: How many cans of cat food did Chad buy?
Chad's cat food total was 6 packages * 9 cans = <<6*9=54>>54 cans of cat food.
How many cans of dog food did Chad buy?
Chad's dog food total was 2 packages * 3 cans = <<2*3=6>>6 cans of dog food.
How many more cans of cat food than dog food did Chad buy?
Chad had 54 cans of cat food - 6 cans of dog food = <<54-6=48>>48 more cans of cat food.

context: Marcus is making calzones. It takes him 20 minutes to saute the onions and a quarter of that time to saute the garlic and peppers. It takes him 30 minutes to knead the dough, twice as long to let it rest, and 1/10th the combined kneading and resting time to assemble the calzones.
main-q: How many minutes does Marcus spend on the calzones total?
qa-pairs: How many minutes does it take Marcus to saute the garlic and peppers?
First find the amount of time it takes Marcus to saute the garlic and peppers: 20 minutes / 4 = <<20/4=5>>5 minutes.
How many minutes does it take Marcus to let the dough rest?
Then find the dough's resting time: 30 minutes * 2 = <<30*2=60>>60 minutes.
How many minutes does it take Marcus to knead and rest the dough?
Then add the kneading and resting time to find the total dough time: 60 minutes + 30 minutes = <<60+30=90>>90 minutes.

context: Stan makes a playlist for the next time he goes running. He has 10 3-minute songs and 15 2-minute songs on his playlist. His entire run takes 100 minutes.
main-q: If Stan wants a playlist to cover his entire run, how many more minutes of songs will he need in his playlist?
qa-pairs: How many minutes of 3-minute songs are on his playlist?
His playlist currently has a playtime of 10 songs * 3 minutes = <<10*3=30>>30 minutes from 3-minute songs.
How many minutes of 2-minute songs are on his playlist?
It also has a playtime of 15 songs * 2 minutes = <<15*2=30>>30 minutes from 2-minute songs.
How many minutes does his playlist last?
So far, his playlist lasts for 30 + 30 = <<30+30=60>>60 minutes.

context: Peter and Kristin are to read 20 fantasy novels each in a week. Peter can read three times as fast as Kristin.
main-q: If Peter reads one book in 18 hours, how long will Kristin read half of her books?
qa-pairs: How many hours will Kristin take to read one book?
Since Peter reads three times as fast as Kristin, Kristin will take 18*3 = <<18*3=54>>54 hours to read one book.
How many books does Kristin read?
Kristin reads half of her books, a total of 20/2 = <<20/2=10>>10 books.
How many hours will Kristin take to read half of her books?
The time Kristin will take to read half of her books is 10*54 = <<10*54=540>>540.

context: There are 6 times as many lab coats as uniforms in the lab. The number of lab techs is half of the number of uniforms.
main-q: If there are 12 uniforms in the lab, and the lab techs share the coats and uniforms equally among them, how many coats and uniforms in total does each lab tech get?
qa-pairs: How many lab coats are there?
If there are 12 uniforms, and the lab coats are 6 times as many as the number of uniforms, there are 6*12 = <<12*6=72>>72 lab coats.
How many coats and uniforms are there in total?
The total number of lab coats and uniforms in the lab is 72+12 = <<72+12=84>>84.
How many lab techs are there?
If the number of lab techs is half the number of uniforms, then there are 12/2 = <<12/2=6>>6 lab techs.

context: Last year, Jorge planted corn on all of his 60 acres of property.  Typically, corn grown on good soil yields 400 bushels per acre, but in clay-rich soil, the yield is only half as much per acre as in good soil.  One-third of Jorge's 60 acres of land is clay-rich soil and the rest is good soil.
main-q: How many bushels of corn did Jorge's land yield last year?
qa-pairs: How many acres of clay-rich soil does Jorge have?
Jorge has 60 * (1/3) = <<60*(1/3)=20>>20 acres of clay-rich soil.
How many acres of good soil does Jorge have?
He has 60 - 20 = <<60-20=40>>40 acres of good soil.
How many bushels of corn did Jorge's land yield last year?
At 400 bushels per acre, his 40 acres of good soil produced 40 * 400 = <<400*40=16000>>16,000 bushels of corn.

context: Jerry is making cherry syrup. He needs 500 cherries per quart of syrup. It takes him 2 hours to pick 300 cherries and 3 hours to make the syrup.
main-q: How long will it take him to make 9 quarts of syrup?
qa-pairs: How many cherries can Jerry pick in one hour?
First find how many cherries Jerry can pick in one hour: 300 cherries / 2 hours = <<300/2=150>>150 cherries/hour.
How many cherries does Jerry need?
Then multiply the number of quarts of syrup by the number of cherries per quart to find the total number of quarts Jerry needs: 500 cherries/quart * 9 quarts = 4500 cherries.
How many hours does it take Jerry to pick the cherries?
Then divide the total number of cherries by the number of cherries he picks per hour to find the number of hours the cherry-picking takes: 4500 cherries / 150 cherries/hour = <<4500/150=30>>30 hours.

context: Camille saw 3 cardinals and four times as many robins as cardinals while bird watching. She also saw twice as many blue jays as cardinals and 1 more than three times as many sparrows as cardinals.
main-q: How many birds did Camille see?
qa-pairs: How many robins did Camille see?
Camille saw 3 x 4 = <<3*4=12>>12 robins.
How many blue jays did Camille see?
She also saw 3 x 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 blue jays.
How many cardinals are there?
Triple the number of cardinals is 3 x 3 = <<3*3=9>>9.

context: Jackson is making dinner. He makes a salad out of lettuce (50 calories), carrots (twice the calories of the lettuce) and dressing (210 calories). He also makes a pizza with 600 calories for the crust, 1/3 the crust's calories for the pepperoni, and 400 calories for the cheese.
main-q: If Jackson eats 1/4 of the salad and 1/5 of the pizza, how many calories does he eat?
qa-pairs: How many calories are in the carrots?
First find the number of calories in the carrots: 50 calories * 2 = <<50*2=100>>100 calories.
How many calories are in the salad?
Then find the total calories in the salad: 100 calories + 50 calories + 210 calories = <<100+50+210=360>>360 calories.
How many calories are in the pepperoni?
Then find the number of calories in the pepperoni: 1/3 * 600 calories = <<1/3*600=200>>200 calories.

context: Julieta went to the store to buy a backpack and three ring-binders for her school supplies. She knew the backpack was $50, and each ring-binder cost was $20. However, at the store, she found out that the price of a back had increased by $5, and the price of a ring-binder had reduced by $2. Calculate the total amount of money Julieta spent at the store.
qa-pairs: How much did the backpack cost initially?
Initially, a backpack cost was $50; when it increased by $5, the price became $50+$5 = $<<50+5=55>>55.
How much did the ring-binder cost initially?
The price of a ring-binder $20, when it reduced by $2, the price became $20-$2 = $<<20-2=18>>18.
How much did Julieta spend on the ring-binders?
If she wanted to buy 3 ring-binders, she spent $18*3 = $<<18*3=54>>54.

context: Haley, Michael and Brandon were trying a marshmallow challenge to see who could hold more marshmallows in their mouths. Haley could hold 8 marshmallows in her mouth. Michael could hold 3 times as many marshmallows as Haley. Brandon could hold half as many as Michael.
main-q: How many total marshmallows did all three kids hold in their mouths?
qa-pairs: How many marshmallows did Haley hold?
Haley held <<8=8>>8 marshmallows.
How many marshmallows did Michael hold?
Michael held 3 times Haley's, so he held 8 x 3 = <<3*8=24>>24 marshmallows.
How many marshmallows did Brandon hold?
Brandon held half as many marshmallows as Michael, so he held 24 / 2 = <<24/2=12>>12 marshmallows.

context: A retailer sells any shirt for the same price and any pair of pants for the same price, but the price of shirts and pants are not the same. Say you bought 2 shirts and 3 pairs of pants for $120 in total, then you realized you didn't need the extra pants.
main-q: What's the price of 1 shirt at this place if when you returned all 3 pairs of pants you were refunded 25% of what you originally paid?
qa-pairs: How much was I refunded?
If I paid $120 and I was refunded 25% for all the 3 pants, then that means I received 25%*120=$<<120*25*.01=30>>30.
How much did the shirts cost?
This means the total price of the 2 shirts was 120-30 = <<120-30=90>>90.
How much does one shirt cost?
The price of one shirt is thus 90/2 = <<90/2=45>>45.

context: Calum runs a nightclub and decides to run a disco night to attract different customers. He is planning the event and is calculating how much he can spend on each item without spending more than he has budgeted. He only needs to buy 4 disco balls and 10 boxes of food. Each box of food costs $25. Calum’s budget for the disco balls and food is $330.
main-q: How much, in dollars, can Calum afford to spend on each disco ball?
qa-pairs: How much will the food cost?
The food is going to cost Calum a total of 10 boxes of food * $25 per box of food = $<<10*25=250>>250.
How much is left to spend on disco balls?
This leaves $330 budget - $250 spent on food = $<<330-250=80>>80 to spend on disco balls.
How much can Calum afford to spend on each disco ball?
Calum can therefore afford to spend $80 remaining budget / 4 disco balls = $<<80/4=20>>20 on each disco ball.

context: Sally Draper gave her dad Don Draper 10oz of rum on his pancakes. Don can consume a maximum of 3 times that amount of rum for a healthy diet.
main-q: If he already had 12oz of rum earlier that day, how many oz of rum can Don have after eating all of the rum and pancakes?
qa-pairs: How much can Don consume for a healthy diet?
3 times the initial amount of 10 oz is 3*10=<<3*10=30>>30 oz.
How much rum has Don consumed, after eating all of the rum and pancakes?
He has consumed 10+12=<<10+12=22>>22 oz of rum.
How many oz of rum can Don still have?
He can still consume 30-22=<<30-22=8>>8 oz of rum.

context: A pen and pencil have a total cost of $6.
main-q: If the pen costs twice as much as the pencil, what is the cost of the pen?
qa-pairs: Define a variable?
Let x be the cost of the pencil.
How much does the pen cost?
If the pen costs 2 times the cost of the pencil, then it costs 2x.
Write an equation?
Adding the cost of the pen and pencil we get 2x + x = 3x.

context: A math teacher had $100 to buy three different types of calculators. A basic calculator costs $8. A scientific calculator costs twice the price as the basic while a graphing calculator costs thrice the price as the scientific.
main-q: How much change did she receive after buying those three different types of calculators?
qa-pairs: How much does a scientific calculator cost?
A scientific calculator costs $8 x 2 = $<<8*2=16>>16.
How much does a graphing calculator cost?
A graphing calculator costs $16 x 3 = $<<16*3=48>>48.
How much did she spend?
So, she spent $8 + $16 + $48 = $<<8+16+48=72>>72 for the three calculators.

context: Tricia buys large bottles of iced coffee that have 6 servings per container.  She drinks half a container a day.  The coffee is currently on sale for $3.00 a bottle.
main-q: How much will it cost her to buy enough bottles to last for 2 weeks?
qa-pairs: How many servings does Tricia drink?
She drinks half a container of a 6 serving bottle of iced coffee a day so she drinks 6/2 = <<6/2=3>>3 servings a day.
How many days does Tricia need?
There are 7 days in a week and she needs enough bottles to last for 2 weeks so that's 7*2 = <<7*2=14>>14 days.
How many servings does Tricia drink?
She drinks 3 servings a day for 14 days so that's 3*14 = <<3*14=42>>42 servings.

context: Last month, a factory made 12000 dolls and their associated accessories.  The accessories for each doll included 2 shoes, 3 bags, 1 set of cosmetics, and 5 hats.
main-q: If each doll took 45 seconds to make and each accessory took 10 seconds to make, what was the total combined machine operation time, in seconds, required to manufacture all of the dolls and their accessories?
qa-pairs: How many shoes did the factory make?
The number of shoes the factory made was 12000 dolls x 2 shoes/doll = <<12000*2=24000>>24000 shoes.
How many bags did the factory make?
The factory also made for each doll 12000 dolls x 3 bags/doll = <<12000*3=36000>>36000 bags.
How many sets of cosmetics did the factory make?
The set of cosmetics made for each doll was just one, so there are <<12000=12000>>12000 cosmetics sets.

context: Lucca has 100 balls and 10 percent of his balls are basketballs. Lucien has 200 balls and 20 percent of them are basketballs.
main-q: In total how many basketballs do Lucca and Lucien have?
qa-pairs: How many basketballs does Lucca have?
Lucca has 100 basketballs x (10 / 100) = <<100*10/100=10>>10 basketballs.
How many basketballs does Lucien have?
Lucien has 200 basketballs x (20 / 100) = <<200*(20/100)=40>>40 basketballs.
How many basketballs do Lucca and Lucien have?
Together they have 10 basketballs + 40 basketballs = <<10+40=50>>50 basketballs.

context: A group of researchers are studying a colony of penguins. Their results show that the size doubled in the first year they watched the colony, then tripled in the next year. This year, however, harsh conditions meant the colony only gained 129 penguins. The colony has 1077 penguins in it now. Each penguin eats one and a half fish every day.
main-q: How many fish did the whole colony catch per day to eat at the beginning of the first year?
qa-pairs: How many penguins were in the colony at the beginning of this year?
The colony had 1077 - 129 = <<1077-129=948>>948 penguins in it at the beginning of this year.
How many penguins were in the colony at the beginning of the second year?
At the beginning of the second year, the colony had 948 / 3 = <<948/3=316>>316 penguins in it.
How many penguins were in the colony at the beginning of the first year?
At the beginning of the first year, it had 316 / 2 = <<316/2=158>>158 penguins in it.

context: Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies plus the difference between the number of Doberman puppies and the number of Schnauzers is equal to 90.
main-q: If the number of Doberman puppies is 20, how many Schnauzers are there?
qa-pairs: How many Doberman puppies are there?
Three times the number of Doberman puppies is 3*20=<<3*20=60>>60.
How many Doberman puppies are there?
Five less than three times the number of Doberman puppies is 60-5=<<60-5=55>>55.
Define a variable?
Let's say the number of Schnauzers is s.

context: In 5 years, Heath will be 3 times as old as Jude.
main-q: If Heath is 16 years old today, how old is Jude today?
qa-pairs: How old will Heath be in 5 years?
In 5 years, Heath will be 16 + 5 = <<16+5=21>>21 years old.
How old will Jude be in 5 years?
In 5 years, Jude will be 21 / 3 = <<21/3=7>>7 years old.
How old is Heath in 5 years?
The difference in their ages is 21 - 7 = <<21-7=14>>14 years.

context: A van is delivering  180 bottles of drinks to a neighborhood, and each bottle contains either cider or beer or a mixture of two. Out of the  180 bottles, 40 contain only cider, 80 contain only beer, and the rest are a mixture of the two drinks.
main-q: If the delivery man gives half the number of each bottle of drink to the first house, how many bottles does the first house get?
qa-pairs: How many bottles contain cider or beer?
The total number of bottles containing cider or beer is 40+80 = <<40+80=120>>120.
How many bottles contain a mixture of the two drinks?
If the number of bottles in the van was 180, then 180-120 =<<180-120=60>>60 contains a mixture of the two drinks.
How many bottles did the first house get?
At the first house, the delivery man dropped 1/2*40 = <<1/2*40=20>>20 bottles.

context: Clementine, Jake, and Tory make cookies for the school bake sale. Clementine baked 72 cookies. Jake baked twice as many cookies as Clementine. Tory baked half as many cookies as Jake and Clementine combined. They sell their cookies for $2 each.
main-q: If they sell all their cookies, how much money do they make?
qa-pairs: How many cookies did Clementine bake?
Clementine baked 72 cookies.
How many cookies did Jake bake?
Jake baked 72 x 2 = <<72*2=144>>144 cookies.
How many cookies did Tory bake?
Tory baked 216 / 2 = <<216/2=108>>108 cookies.

context: A dog is being treated for fleas. One flea treatment gets rid of half the fleas. After four treatments, the dog has 14 fleas left.
main-q: How many more fleas did the dog have before the flea treatments than after?
qa-pairs: How many fleas did the dog have after three treatments?
After three treatments, the dog had 14 * 2 = <<14*2=28>>28 fleas.
How many fleas did the dog have after two treatments?
After two treatments, the dog had 28 * 2 = <<28*2=56>>56 fleas.
How many fleas did the dog have after one treatment?
After one treatment, the dog had 56 * 2 = <<56*2=112>>112 fleas.

context: Between them, Mark and Sarah have 24 traffic tickets. Mark has twice as many parking tickets as Sarah, and they each have an equal number of speeding tickets.
main-q: If Sarah has 6 speeding tickets, how many parking tickets does Mark have?
qa-pairs: How many speeding tickets did Sarah and Mark get together?

context: Ken likes to bike when it's raining and can cycle 30 miles in 20 minutes during this time. However, when it's snowing Ken can't stand the cold and can only cycle 10 miles in 20 minutes.

context: In the spelling bee, Max has 5 points, Dulce has 3 points, and Val has twice the combined points of Max and Dulce.

context: Cleo and Ignacio placed 30 of their marbles in a jar on a Monday. They took 3/5 of the marbles from the jar the next day and divided them equally. On the third day, Cleo took 1/2 of the marbles remaining in the jars.
main-q: How many marbles did Cleo have on the third day?

The total number of marbles remaining in the jar is 30 marbles - 18 marbles = <<30-18=12>>12 marbles.

context: A group of 5 children are taken to an amusement park. Only 3 of them were daring enough to get on the Ferris wheel which cost $5 per child. Everyone had a go at the merry-go-round (at $3 per child). On their way home, they bought 2 cones of ice cream each (each cone cost $8).

context: Sam the butcher made sausage by grinding up 10 pounds of spicy meat mix, loading it into a tube casing, and creating a string of 40 sausage links. Then, she hung up the string of sausage links in her cooler.  Later that evening, Brandy, Sam’s Golden Retriever, broke into the cooler and ate 12 links of sausage.

There are 16 ounces in one pound, and thus in 10 pounds of meat mix there are 10*16=<<10*16=160>>160 ounces of sausage meat.

Thus, the 40 sausage links contained 160 ounces of meat, or 160/40=<<160/40=4>>4 ounces per link.

If Brandy ate 12 links, then 40-12=<<40-12=28>>28 links remained.

context: Lucius owns a small business and spends $10 every day on ingredients. He then makes a portion of French Fries and a portion of Poutine and sells them to the market, paying ten percent of his weekly income as tax.

How much does he pay in taxes?
And the total amount he pays for the taxes is $140 x 0.10= $<<140*0.10=14>>14.

context: A cake has 8 slices and each slice contains 347 calories.  A pan of brownies has 6 brownies and each slice contains 375 calories.

context: Brogan has two apple trees and goes to harvest them. The first tree is 40% red and 60% green. The second tree is 50% red and 50% green.
main-q: If they each produce 20 apples, how many red apples does he get?

context: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20.

context: There are 50 goldfish in the pond. Each goldfish eats 1.5 ounces of food per day. 20% of the goldfish need to eat special food that costs $3 an ounce.

context: Three towns, Toadon, Gordonia, and Lake Bright, have 80000 people. Gordonia has 1/2 times the total population in the three cities.

How many people live in Toadon?

context: At the beginning of an academic year, there were 15 boys in a class and the number of girls was 20% greater. Later in the year, transfer students were admitted such that the number of girls doubled but the number of boys remained the same.

context: Clare's mother gave her $47 to go to the store. Clare bought 4 loaves of bread and 2 cartons of milk. Each loaf of bread cost $2 and each carton of milk cost $2.

context: Karen bakes 50 chocolate chip cookies. She keeps 10 for herself, and she gives 8 to her grandparents.

context: Mandy bought 3 packs of black shirts and 3 packs of yellow shirts for her tennis team. The black shirts come in packs of 5, and the yellow shirts come in packs of 2.

context: In Hawaii, they normally get an average of 2 inches of rain a day. With 100 days left in the year, they've gotten 430 inches of rain.

context: Rose bought her mother one dozen flowers. Two of the flowers are daisies. Three-fifths of the remaining flowers are tulips and the rest are sunflowers.

context: In a forest, there are three anthills. In the first anthill, there are 100 ants, and in each next anthill, there are 20% fewer ants than in the previous one.

This means there are 100 - 20 = <<100-20=80>>80 ants in the second anthill.

context: Mitch has saved $20000 to finance his boating hobby. A new boat costs $1500 per foot in length.

context: Bill gets paid $20 every hour he works up to a total of 40 hours, after which he gets paid double that amount per hour.

context: Melody needs to read 20 pages for her English class, 16 pages for her Science class, 8 pages for her Civics, and 12 pages for Chinese class. She decided to read one-fourth of the number of pages for each class tomorrow.

context: A judge oversaw seventeen court cases. Two were immediately dismissed from court. Two-thirds of the remaining cases were ruled innocent, one ruling was delayed until a later date, and the rest were judged guilty.

context: Lidia has a collection of books. Her collection is four times bigger than the collection which her friend Susan has. In total Susan and Lidia, both have 3000 books.

context: Pulsar, the shuffle-dancing bear, Polly, the pink prancing poodle, and Petra, the proud portly pachyderm, are entertainers at the Big Top Circus. context: At a party, there are 400 students, a combination of poets, singers and tree huggers. There are 50 more poets than treehuggers at the party.

context: Colston knows that his teacher loves drinking coffee and one day wants to see how much she drinks each week. context: Big Dig Mining Company mines three different types of ore: copper, iron, and nickel. Across all their mines, 10% of their output is nickel, 60% is iron, and the rest is copper. They mine 720 tons of nickel a day.

qa-pairs: Define a variable?

context: Buffy has a sailboat with a planing hull that she sails in the Gulf of Mexico.  Under optimal wind conditions, the use of two sails brings the ship to the speed of 50 knots, whereas under the same conditions, the use of one sail brings her ship to the speed of 25 knots. main-q: If she travels in her sailboat under optimal wind conditions for 4 hours with one sail and then for another 4 hours with two sails, what is the total distance, in land miles, that she will travel?
qa-pairs: How far will she travel with 1 sail?

How far will she travel with 2 sails?
Under optimal wind conditions, if her ship sails 4 hours with 2 sails, she will travel 4*50=<<4*50=200>>200 nautical miles.
How far will she travel in total?
In total, she will travel 100+200=<<100+200=300>>300 nautical miles.

context: Abraham is buying some toiletries and creates a budget of $60 for his shopping. He buys 4 shower gels for $4 each, a tube of toothpaste for $3, and a box of laundry detergent.

context: Annie goes to school. Today is her birthday, so Annie decided to buy some sweets for her colleagues. Every classmate got 2 candies. In the end, Annie got left with 12 candies. If there are 35 people in Annie's class in total, how much did Annie spend on candies, if one candy costs $0.

context: Andrew eats 14 donuts on Monday, and half as many on Tuesday. On Wednesday Andrew eats 4 times as many as he did on Monday.

context: Solomon collected three times as many cans as Juwan. Levi collected half of what Juwan collected. Solomon collected 66 cans.

context: Kimiko watches four YouTube videos. The first video is 2 minutes long, the second video is 4 minutes and 30 seconds, and the last two videos are equal in length.
main-q: If she spends a total of 510 seconds watching YouTube, how many seconds long was each of the last two videos?

How many seconds are in the second video?

How many seconds did Kimiko spend watching?

Now subtract the length of the first two videos from the total time Kimiko spent watching to find the combined length of the last two videos: 510 seconds - 120 seconds - 270 seconds = <<510-120-270=120>>120 seconds.

context: Justin wanted to watch a movie that came on at 8 pm that night.  His parents agreed as long as he finished his homework and chores before the movie started. context: Kristine traveled to Paris in France to visit her friend. On the way, she has driven a train for 300 km and a bus for half that distance. After arriving in the city, she had to take a cab and drove three times fewer kilometers than she rode the bus.

context: Nicholas bought six times as much fabric as Kenneth. If Kenneth paid $40 for an oz of fabric and bought 700oz, calculate the amount of money that Nicholas paid more than Kenneth for the fabric he bought.

context: Linda was going to pass out homemade cookies to each of her 24 classmates on the last day of school. context: Pierre decides to bring his mother out for ice cream. His treat. Each scoop is $2.

context: A mother is serving pizza at her son's birthday party. context: Bob and Johnny have a leaf raking business. They charge $4 for each bag of leaves they rake. On Monday they raked 5 bags of leaves. On Tuesday they raked 3 bags of leaves. On Wednesday, they counted their money and found they had $68 for all three days.

context: A tree had 1000 leaves before the onset of the dry season, when it sheds all its leaves. In the first week of the dry season, the tree shed 2/5 of the leaves. context: Nancy takes 3 antacids per day when she eats Indian food, 2 antacids per day when she eats Mexican food, and 1 antacid per day otherwise.

Then find the number of days she doesn't eat Indian food or Mexican food: 7 days/week - 3 days/week - 2 days/week = 2 days/week.

context: Two buses leave a pick-up point station with 60% and 70% of capacity full, respectively.

The total number of people in the two buses is 105+90 = <<105+90=195>>195.

context: Bobby has an aquarium with twice as many fish as Sarah's has.  Sarah has 5 more fish in her aquarium than Tony does.  Tony has 3 times as many fish in his aquarium as Billy does.  Billy has 10 fish.

context: Andrew's father buys a package of 100 masks. Andrew lives with his 2 parents and 2 siblings. All members of Andrew's family change masks every 4 days.

context: McKenna has 34 stuffed animals. Kenley has twice as many as McKenna.  Tenly has 5 more than Kenley .

context: In a movie theater, the admission costs $8 but the price is $3 less if you watch the movie before 6 P.M. Kath takes her 2 siblings and 3 of her friends to a movie which starts at 4 P.M.

context: Kelly, Brittany, and Buffy went swimming at Salt Rock Lake and held a contest to see who could hold their breath underwater for the longest amount of time. context: Suzanna's history textbook has 160 pages and her geography textbook has 70 more pages. Her math textbook has half of the sum of the first two books' pages, and her science textbook has twice the number of pages of her history textbook.

context: Jackson had 20 kilograms of meat. He used 1/4 of the meat to make meatballs and used 3 kilograms of meat to make spring rolls.

context: For every white duck at the lake there are 5 fish.  For every black duck there are 10 fish and for every multicolor duck there are 12 fish.  Currently there are 3 white ducks, 7 black ducks and 6 multicolored ducks.

context: On Monday Elisa paints 30 square feet of her house's walls. On Tuesday she paints twice that amount. On Wednesday she finishes up by painting half as many square feet as she painted on Monday.

context: The distance between Arizona and New York is around 2,000 miles by plane. The distance between the 2 different US states increases by 40% if someone decides to drive instead of flying. Missouri is midway between Arizona and New York.

context: Anna is reading a 31-chapter textbook, but she skips all the chapters that are divisible by 3.

context: Tony exercises every morning by walking 3 miles carrying a 25-pound backpack, then he runs another 10 miles without the backpack.

context: Francine wants to know if a local chemical plant is releasing toxic waste that makes the frogs mutate. In one local pond, she catches 5 frogs with extra legs, 2 frogs with 2 heads, two frogs that are bright red, and 18 normal frogs.
main-q: What percentage of the frogs have mutated, rounded to the nearest integer?

How many frogs are there?

What percentage of the frogs have mutated?

Finally, divide the number of mutant frogs by the total number of frogs and multiply by 100% to find the percentage of frogs that are mutants: 9 frogs / 27 frogs * 100% = 33.333...%, which rounds to 33%.

context: Mary is paying her monthly garbage bill for a month with exactly four weeks. context: There are 3 bicycles, 4 tricycles and 7 unicycles in the garage at Zoe's house. Each bicycle has 2 wheels, each tricycle has 3 wheels and each unicycle has 1 wheel.

context: Sid takes $48 with him on a shopping trip to the mall.  He spent some of his money on computer accessories and another $8 on snacks. After these purchases, he only has $4 more than half of his original money left.

context: Cara has 60 marbles in a bag. 20 of them are yellow, half as many are green, and the remaining marbles are equally divided between red and blue.

context: Jane sews 2 dresses a day for 7 days. Then she sews 3 dresses a day for the next 2 days. In the end, she adds 2 ribbons to each dress.

context: Mrs. Watson is grading 120 final exams from her American History class.  On Monday, she grades 60% of the exams.  On Tuesday, she grades 75% of the remaining exams.

context: Matias is a salesman in a bookstore. He sold 7 books on Tuesday and three times as many on Wednesday.

context: On March 1st the sun sets at 6 PM.  Every day after the sun sets 1.2 minutes later.  It is 6:10 PM and 40 days after March 1st.

context: A Lamplighter monkey has long arms and can swing from branch to branch at a speed of 10 feet per second.  But when the monkey is frightened, it will run along the branches at a speed of 15 feet per second.

context: There are twice as many cows as dogs at a petting farm.

context: Billy ate 20 apples this week. On Monday, he ate 2 apples. On Tuesday, he ate twice as many as he ate the day before. He’s not sure what he ate on Wednesday. On Thursday, he ate four times as many as he ate on Friday. On Friday, he ate half of the amount he ate on Monday.

context: Biff and Kenneth decide to compete in a 500-yard rowboat race.

context: In a classroom, there are blue chairs, green chairs, and white chairs. There are 10 blue chairs. The green chairs are 3 times as many as the blue chairs, and there are 13 fewer white chairs than the green and blue chairs combined.

context: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water.

context: Cristian has 50 more black cookies in his cookie jar than white cookies. He eats half of the black cookies and 3/4 of the white cookies.

context: There are 2000 pinecones on the ground. 20% are eaten by reindeer. Twice as many are eaten by squirrels as reindeer. 25% of the remainder are collected to make fires.
main-q: How many pinecones are left?

First find the number of pinecones eaten by reindeer: 20% * 2000 pinecones = <<20*.01*2000=400>>400 pine cones.
How many pine cones are eaten by squirrels?

context: There are four growing trees. The first tree grows 1 meter/day, the second grows the same amount in half the time, the third grows 2 meters/day, and the fourth tree grows a meter more than the third each day.

qa-pairs: How many meters does the second tree grow in a day?
The second tree grows 1*2 = <<1*2=2>>2 meters a day.
How many meters does the fourth tree grow in a day?
The fourth tree grows 2+1 = <<2+1=3>>3 meters a day.
How many meters does the first tree grow in 4 days?
The first tree grows 4*1 = <<4*1=4>>4 meters in 4 days.

context: Yuko likes to play board games. He decides to play a game with his brother Yuri. They must roll 3 dice at the same time and move the squares corresponding to the value of the 3 dice. Yuri started and his dice had the following combination: 2, 4, and 5. On Yuko's turn, he rolled 1, 5, and X.
main-q: How many squares must Yuko's last die move him so that he is in front of his brother?
qa-pairs: How many squares did Yuri's dice give?
The sum of Yuri's dice gave, 2 + 4 + 5 = <<2+4+5=11>>11 squares.
How many squares did Yuko's dice give?
For Yuko to get the same sum in the dice, 1 + 5 + X = 11 squares.
How many squares did Yuko's last die move him so that he is in front of his brother?
Solving the equation, X = 11 - 6, X = <<11-6=5>>5 squares.

context: James does chores around the class.  There are 3 bedrooms, 1 living room, and 2 bathrooms to clean.  The bedrooms each take 20 minutes to clean.  The living room takes as long as the 3 bedrooms combined.  The bathroom takes twice as long as the living room.  He also cleans the outside which takes twice as long as cleaning the house.  He splits the chores with his 2 siblings who are just as fast as him.
main-q: How long, in hours, does he work?
qa-pairs: How long does it take to clean the living room?
It takes 3*20=<<3*20=60>>60 minutes to clean the living room.
How long does it take to clean the living room?
How long does it take to clean the bathroom?
The bathroom takes 1*2=<<1*2=2>>2 hours.

context: Zoe goes to the store to buy soda and pizza for herself and her 5 family members. Each bottle of soda costs half a dollar and each slice of pizza costs $1. Before she leaves her house she takes just enough money to pay for her purchase.
main-q: How much money did Zoe take?
qa-pairs: How many people are going to eat pizza and soda?
Zoe is going to buy pizza and soda for 5 people + 1 person = <<5+1=6>>6 people.
How much will Zoe pay for 6 sodas?
For 6 sodas, Zoe will pay 6 sodas * $0.5/soda = $<<6*0.5=3>>3.
How much will Zoe pay for 6 slices of pizza?
For 6 slices of pizza, she will pay 6 slices * $1/slice = $<<6*1=6>>6.

context: This morning, farmer Rita's workers collected 30,000 gallons of milk and chilled it in a storage tank. They then spent the next 4 hours pumping milk at a rate of 2,880 gallons/hour from the storage tank into a milk tanker. For the next 7 hours, the workers added more milk into the storage tank, at a rate of 1,500 gallons per hour.
main-q: How many gallons of milk were left in the storage tank?
qa-pairs: How many gallons of milk did the tanker get in the first 4 hours?
In the first 4 hours, the milk tanker got 4 hours * 2880 gallons/hour = <<4*2880=11520>>11,520 gallons.
How many gallons of milk were left in the storage tank?
Thus, the storage tank was left with 30,000 gallons - 11,520 gallons = <<30000-11520=18480>>18,480 gallons.
How many gallons of milk were added to the storage tank in the next 7 hours?
For the next 7 hrs, the workers added 1,500 gallons/hour * 7 hours = <<1500*7=10500>>10,500 gallons.

context: A seminar is offered to a school for their teachers. The regular seminar fee is $150 but they offer a 5% discount if they register 2 days before the scheduled seminar. The school registered 10 teachers for the seminar a week before the schedule and it also released a $10 food allowance for each of the teachers.
main-q: How much did the school spend in all?
qa-pairs: How much did the school get a discount on the seminar fee?
The school got a $150 x 5/100 = $<<150*5/100=7.50>>7.50 seminar fee discount for each teacher.
How much did each teacher's seminar fee cost?
Each teacher's seminar fee costs $150 - $7.50 = $<<150-7.5=142.50>>142.50.
How much did the school spend in all?
So, ten teachers' seminar fees cost $142.50 x 10 = $1425.

context: Aliyah has 10 more phones than her sister Vivienne.
main-q: If  Vivienne has 40 phones, and the two sisters sell their phones at $400 each, calculate the total amount of money they have together?
qa-pairs: How much money does Vivienne get from selling her phones?
The total amount of money that Vivienne gets from selling her phones is 40*400 = <<40*400=16000>>16000.
How many phones does Aliyah have?
Since Aliyah has 10 more phones than Vivienne, she has 40+10 = <<10+40=50>>50 phones.
How much money does Aliyah get from selling her phones?
When she sells her phones, Aliyah receives 50*$400= $<<50*400=20000>>20000.

context: The battery charge in Mary’s cordless vacuum cleaner lasts ten minutes. It takes her four minutes to vacuum each room in her house. Mary has three bedrooms, a kitchen, and a living room.
main-q: How many times does Mary need to charge her vacuum cleaner to vacuum her whole house?
qa-pairs: How many rooms are in Mary’s house?
Mary has 3 + 1 + 1 = <<3+1+1=5>>5 rooms in her house.
How many minutes will it take Mary to vacuum her whole house?
At 4 minutes a room, it will take her 4 * 5 = <<4*5=20>>20 minutes to vacuum her whole house.
How many times does Mary need to charge her vacuum cleaner to vacuum her whole house?
At 10 minutes a charge, she will need to charge her vacuum cleaner 20 / 10 = <<20/10=2>>2 times to vacuum her whole house.

context: Hannah wanted to make an apple pie that would serve 8 people.  She needed 2 pounds of apples that were on sale for $2.00 per pound. The pre-made pie crust cost $2.00.  The lemon cost $.50 and the butter cost $1.50.
main-q: How much did each serving of pie cost?
qa-pairs: How much would the apples cost?
2 pounds of apples at $2.00/pound would cost 2*2 = $<<2*2=4.00>>4.00.
How much did the pie cost?
If we add all of the purchases together then the total bill was 4+2+.50+1.50 = $<<4+2+.50+1.50=8.00>>8.00.
How much did each serving of pie cost?
There are 8 servings per pie. So $8.00/8 servings = $1.00 per serving.

context: Isabela bought twice as many cucumbers as pencils, with both costing $20 each. If she got a 20% discount on the pencils and bought 100 cucumbers, calculate the total amount she spent to buy the items.
qa-pairs: How many pencils did Isabela buy?
Isabela bought twice as many cucumbers as pencils, meaning she bought 100/2 = <<100/2=50>>50 pencils.
How much did Isabela spend on the pencils?
The total cost for purchasing the pencils without the discount is 50*$20 = $<<50*20=1000>>1000.
How much did Isabela pay in total?

context: Brayden and Gavin were playing touch football against Cole and Freddy. Touchdowns were worth 7 points. Brayden and Gavin scored 7 touchdowns. Cole and Freddy's team scored 9 touchdowns.
main-q: How many more points did Cole and Freddy have than Brayden and Gavin?
qa-pairs: How many points did Brayden and Gavin score?
Brayden and Gavin scored 7 touchdowns * 7 points each = <<7*7=49>>49 points.
How many points did Cole and Freddy score?
Cole and Freddy scored 9 touchdowns * 7 points each = <<9*7=63>>63 points.
How many more points did Cole and Freddy have than Brayden and Gavin?
Cole and Freddy's team had 63 - 49 points = <<63-49=14>>14 points more than Brayden and Gavin's team.

context: Jerry owes a loan shark $200. The loan shark charges Jerry 10% interest compounded monthly. (This means that every month the loan shark adds Jerry's interest amount to his loan, and the next month Jerry has to pay 10% on the new total).
main-q: If Jerry doesn't make any payments, how much (in dollars) does the loan shark charge in interest the second month?
qa-pairs: How much does the loan shark charge in interest the first month?
First calculate how much the loan shark charges in interest the first month by multiplying the loan amount by the interest rate: $200 * 10% = $<<200*10*.01=20>>20.
How much does Jerry owe after the first month?
Now add the interest amount to the original amount of the loan to find Jerry's new total: $200 + $20 = $<<200+20=220>>220.
How much does the loan shark charge in interest the second month?
Now multiply the new total by 10% to find out how much Jerry owes the loan shark in interest the second month: $220 * 10% = $<<220*10*.01=22>>22.

context: There are 100 people in a theater.
main-q: If 19 of these people have blue eyes, half of them have brown eyes, a quarter have black eyes, and the rest have green eyes, how many of them have green eyes?
qa-pairs: How many people have brown eyes?
100/2 = <<100/2=50>>50 people in the theater have brown eyes.
How many people have black eyes?
100/4 = <<100/4=25>>25 people in the theater have black eyes.
How many people have brown, black, or blue eyes?
There are 50+25+19 = <<50+25+19=94>>94 people in the theater with either brown, black, or blue eyes.

context: On Monday, a restaurant sells forty dinners. On Tuesday, it sells 40 more dinners than it did Monday. On Wednesday, it sells half the amount of dinners it sold on Tuesday. On Thursday they changed their recipe, and then sold 3 more dinners than they did on Wednesday.
main-q: How many dinners were sold in those 4 days?
qa-pairs: How many dinners were sold on Tuesday?
On Tuesday the restaurant sells 40+40 = <<40+40=80>>80 dinners.
How many dinners were sold on Wednesday?
On Wednesday the restaurant sells 80/2 = <<80/2=40>>40 dinners.
How many dinners were sold on Thursday?
On Thursday the restaurant sells 40+3 = <<40+3=43>>43 dinners.

context: Mindy has 7 less than 9 times as many emails waiting for her as phone messages.
main-q: If she has a total of 93 emails and phone messages combined, how many emails does she have?
qa-pairs: How many emails does Mindy have?
Let e be the number of emails Mindy has and m be the number of phone messages? We know that e + m = 93 and e = 9m - 7.
How many phone messages does Mindy have?
Substituting the second equation into the first equation, we get 9m - 7 + m = 93.
How many phone messages does Mindy have?
Combining like terms, we get 10m - 7 = 93.

context: Zayne sells bracelets for $5 each and two for $8.
main-q: If he started with 30 bracelets and made $60 from selling bracelets for $5 each, how much in total did he make from selling his bracelets?
qa-pairs: How many bracelets did Zayne sell at $5?
If the bracelets he sold at $5 made $60, he sold $60/$5 = <<60/5=12>>12 bracelets.
How many bracelets did Zayne sell?
If the total number of $5 bracelets was 12, then the total number of bracelets he sold was 30-12 =18.
How many pairs of bracelets did Zayne sell?
If he was selling a pair of bracelets at $8, he sold 18/2 = 9 pairs.

context: Jeff orders a Halloween costume.  He has to put in a 10% deposit and then pay the rest when he picks it up.  The costume is 40% more expensive than last year's costume, which cost $250.
main-q: How much did he pay when picking it up, in dollars?
qa-pairs: How much did his old costume cost?
It cost 250*.4=$<<250*.4=100>>100 more than his old costume.
How much did his new costume cost?
How much did Jeff leave as a deposit?

context: Peggy has 6 dolls.  Her grandmother gives Peggy her own collection of 30 dolls.  Over the year, Peggy receives half that amount of dolls between her birthday and Christmas.
main-q: How many dolls does Peggy now have?
qa-pairs: How many dolls does Peggy have?
Peggy has 6 dolls and her grandmother gave her 30 so that’s 6+30 = <<6+30=36>>36 dolls.
How many dolls does Peggy receive over the holidays?
Over the holidays, Peggy is gifted half the number of dolls her grandmother gave her, so she receives 30/2 = <<30/2=15>>15 more dolls.
How many dolls does Peggy now have?
Peggy had 36 dolls and received another 15 for a total of 36+15 = <<36+15=51>>51 dolls.

context: Nick is asking all his co-workers to chip in for a birthday gift for Sandra that costs $100. The boss agrees to contribute $15, and Todd volunteers to contribute twice as much since he always has to one-up everyone.
main-q: If the remaining 5 employees (counting Nick) each pay an equal amount, how much do they each pay?
qa-pairs: How much does Todd contribute?
First find Todd's contribution by doubling the boss's contribution: $15 * 2 = $<<15*2=30>>30.
How much does Nick's co-workers need to pay?
Now subtract Todd and the boss's contributions to find out how much still needs to be paid: $100 - $30 - $15 = $<<100-30-15=55>>55.
How much do Nick's co-workers each pay?
Now divide the remaining cost by the number of employees to find the cost per employee: $55 / 5 employees = $<<55/5=11>>11/employee.

context: Danny has 3 bottles of soda. He drinks 90% of one bottle and gives 70% of the other two bottles to his friends.
main-q: How much soda does Danny have left, expressed as a percentage of a bottle?
qa-pairs: How much soda did Danny drink?
First find how much soda Danny drank: 1 bottle * .9 = <<1*.9=.9>>.9 bottles.
How much soda did Danny give to his friends?
Then find how much soda Danny gave to his friends: 2 friends * 1 bottle/friend * .7 = <<2*1*.7=1.4>>1.4 bottles.
How much soda does Danny have left?
Now subtract the soda drunk and given away to find the remaining amount of soda: 3 bottles - .9 bottles - 1.4 bottles = .7 bottles * 100% = 70%.

context: Joanie wants to join a gym to get into shape. The gym costs $12 per month and has a $50 down payment.
main-q: How much will she need to pay for the first 3 years?
qa-pairs: How much does the membership cost?
The membership costs $12 * 12 months = $<<12*12=144>>144 per year.
How much will the membership cost for three years?
For three years, the monthly membership fee will be $144 * 3 = $<<144*3=432>>432.
How much will Joanie pay for the first 3 years?
The total amount paid for 3 years will be $432 + $50 = $<<432+50=482>>482.

context: James needs to get a new pair of glasses.  His frames cost $200 and the lenses cost $500.  Insurance will cover 80% of the cost of lenses and he has a $50 off coupon for frames.
main-q: How much does everything cost?
qa-pairs: How much does insurance cover?
He gets 500*.8=$<<500*.8=400>>400 off the cost of lenses.
How much do the lenses cost?
That means the lenses cost 500-400=$<<500-400=100>>100.
How much do the frames cost?

context: As firefighters, Doug, Kai, and Eli have been putting out a lot of fires over the week. Doug has put out 20 fires for the week and Kai has put out 3 times more than Doug. Meanwhile, Eli has put out half the number of fires Kai was able to.
main-q: How many fires have they put out for the entire week?
qa-pairs: How many fires has Kai put out?
Kai has put out 20 x 3 = <<20*3=60>>60 fires for the week.
How many fires has Eli put out?
Eli has put out 60 / 2 = <<60/2=30>>30 fires for the week.
How many fires have they put out for the entire week?
Therefore, the total amount of fires they have put out over the entire week was 20 + 60 + 30 = <<20+60+30=110>>110.

context: There are 88 dogs in a park. 12 of the dogs are running. Half of them are playing with toys. A fourth of them are barking.
main-q: How many dogs are not doing anything?
qa-pairs: How many dogs are playing with toys?
88/2 = <<88/2=44>>44 dogs are playing with toys.
How many dogs are barking?
88/4 = <<88/4=22>>22 dogs are barking.
How many dogs are not doing anything?
88-12-44-22 = <<88-12-44-22=10>>10 dogs are not doing anything.

context: Arabella is a dance student learning three new steps this session. Her instructor has her spend thirty minutes on learning the first step. The second step she masters in half the time. The third step is more complex, so it takes her as long as both the other steps to learn.
main-q: How many minutes did she spend learning the three steps?
qa-pairs: How many minutes did she spend on the second step?
Arabella spent 30 / 2 = <<30/2=15>>15 minutes on the second step.
How many minutes did she take to learn the third step?
She took 30 + 15 = <<30+15=45>>45 minutes to learn the third step.
How many minutes did she spend learning the three steps?
Therefore, Arabella spent 30 + 15 + 45 = <<30+15+45=90>>90 minutes learning all three steps.

context: Tyson played basketball on the schoolyard. He scored three points fifteen times, and two points twelve times. He also scored one point some number of times.
main-q: How many times did he score one point, if in total he scored 75 points?
qa-pairs: How many points did Tyson score?
Tyson scored three points fifteen times, which would be 3 * 15 = <<3*15=45>>45 points.
How many points did Tyson score?
He also scored two points twelve times, which would give him a score of 2 * 12 = <<2*12=24>>24.
How many points did Tyson score?
So Tyson scored 75 - 45 - 24 = <<75-45-24=6>>6 points, by one point each.

context: There are 360 balls in the ball pit. If a quarter of the balls in the ball pit are red and a fifth of the remaining balls are blue.
main-q: How many of the balls are neither red nor blue?
qa-pairs: How many red balls are there?
A quarter of the balls are red and therefore there are 360 x (1 / 4) = <<360*(1/4)=90>>90 red balls.
How many balls are remaining?
When you remove the red balls from the ball pit there are 360 - 90 = <<360-90=270>>270 remaining balls.
How many blue balls are there?
A fifth of the remaining balls are blue, and therefore there are 270 x (1 / 5) = <<270*(1/5)=54>>54 blue balls.

context: John had $20. He spent 1/5 of his money on snacks and 3/4 of the remaining money on necessities.
main-q: How much is left of John's money?
qa-pairs: How much did John spend on snacks?
John spent $20 x 1/5 = $<<20*1/5=4>>4 on snacks.
How much money did John have left?
How much did John spend on necessities?
He spent $16 x 3/4 = $<<16*3/4=12>>12 on his necessities.

context: After geometry class, Bill wants to count how many lines he drew. For each shape, he drew one line per side.
main-q: If he drew 12 triangles, 8 squares, and 4 pentagons, how many lines did he draw?
qa-pairs: How many lines did Bill draw for the triangles?
For the triangles, he drew 36 lines because 12 times 3 equals <<12*3=36>>36.
How many lines did Bill draw for the squares?
For the squares, he drew 32 lines because 8 times 4 equals <<8*4=32>>32.
How many lines did Bill draw for the pentagons?
For the pentagons, he drew 20 lines because 4 times 5 equals <<4*5=20>>20.

context: Martha spends 10 minutes turning the router off and on again, six times that long on hold with Comcast, and half as much time as she spent on hold yelling at a customer service representative.
main-q: How much time did Martha spend on these activities total?
qa-pairs: How many minutes did Martha spend on hold?
First find the total time Martha spent on hold: 10 minutes * 6 = <<10*6=60>>60 minutes.
How many minutes did Martha spend yelling?
Then find the time she spent yelling: 60 minutes / 2 = <<60/2=30>>30 minutes.
How much time did Martha spend on these activities total?
Then add all the amount of time to find the total time: 60 minutes + 30 minutes + 10 minutes = <<60+30+10=100>>100 minutes.

context: In a 100-item exam, Lowella got 35% of the questions correctly. Pamela got 20% more correct answers than Lowella and Mandy got twice Pamela's score.
main-q: What is Mandy’s score?
qa-pairs: How many correct answers did Lowella get?
Lowella got 100 x 35/100 = <<100*35/100=35>>35 correct answers.
How many more correct answers did Pamela get than Lowella?
Pamela got 35 x 20/100 = <<35*20/100=7>>7 more correct answers than Lowella.
How many correct answers did Pamela get?
So, Pamela got 35 + 7 = <<35+7=42>>42 correct answers.

context: John wants to start a zoo.  He has 15 snakes.  He has twice as many monkeys as he does snakes.  He has 5 fewer lions than he does monkeys.   John has 8 more pandas than he does lions.  John has 1/3 as many dogs as he does pandas.
main-q: How many total animals does John have?
qa-pairs: How many monkeys does John have?
John has 15 snakes * 2 = <<15*2=30>>30 monkeys.
How many lions does John have?
John has 30 monkeys - 5 = <<30-5=25>>25 lions.
How many pandas does John have?
John has 25 lions + 8 = <<25+8=33>>33 pandas.

context: James wants to build a ladder to climb a very tall tree.  Each rung of the ladder is 18 inches long and they are 6 inches apart.
main-q: If he needs to climb 50 feet how many feet of wood will he need for the rungs?
qa-pairs: How many rungs does James need?
He needs 12/6=<<12/6=2>>2 rungs per foot.
How many rungs does James need?
So he needs 50*2=<<50*2=100>>100 rungs.
How long is each rung?

context: Sofia went to the department store to buy a pair of shoes and 2 shirts. A shirt costs $7 while a pair of shoes is $3 more than the shirt.
main-q: If she decides to buy a bag which costs half the total price of the 2 shirts and a pair of shoes, how much will she pay for all those items?
qa-pairs: How much do the shirts cost?
Two shirts costs $7 x 2 = $<<7*2=14>>14.
How much do the shoes cost?
The cost of a pair of shoes is $7 + $3 = $<<7+3=10>>10.
How much do the shirts and shoes cost together?
The total cost of two shirts a pair of shoes is $14 + $10 = $<<14+10=24>>24.

context: Jon runs a website where he gets paid for every person who visits.  He gets paid $0.10 for every person who visits.  Each hour he gets 50 visits.  His website operates 24 hours a day.
main-q: How many dollars does he make in a 30 day month?
qa-pairs: How much does Jon make in an hour?
How much does Jon make in a day?
How much does Jon make in a month?

context: Fern buys one pair of high heels for $60 and five pairs of ballet slippers for 2/3rds of the price of the high heels.
main-q: How much does she pay total?
qa-pairs: How much does one pair of ballet slippers cost?
First find the cost of one pair of ballet slippers: $60 * 2/3 = $<<60*2/3=40>>40.
How much do the ballet slippers cost in total?
Then find the total cost of the ballet slippers: $40/pair * 5 pairs = $<<40*5=200>>200.
How much does Fern pay total?
Then add that amount to the cost of the high heels to find the total cost: $200 + $60 = $<<200+60=260>>260.

context: Six Grade 4 sections launched a recycling drive where they collect old newspapers to recycle. Each section collected 280 kilos in two weeks. After the third week, they found that they need 320 kilos more to reach their target.
main-q: How many kilos of the newspaper is their target?
qa-pairs: How many kilos did each section collect in a week?
In a week, each section collected 280/2 = <<280/2=140>>140 kilos of newspapers.
How many kilos did each section collect in three weeks?
So, in three weeks, one section collected 140 x 3 = <<140*3=420>>420 kilos.
How many kilos did the four sections collect in total?
So, the four sections collected a total of 420 x 4 = <<420*4=1680>>1680 kilos.

context: Noel bakes 4 dozen donuts for his class. There are 30 students in class, but only 80% like donuts.
main-q: How many donuts does each student who likes donuts get to eat?
qa-pairs: How many donuts does Noel make?
He makes 48 donuts because 4 x 12 = <<4*12=48>>48.
How many students want to eat donuts?
24 students want to eat donuts because 30 x .8 = <<30*.8=24>>24.
How many donuts can each student eat?
They can each eat 2 donuts because 48 / 24 = <<48/24=2>>2.

context: In the last 25 years, 60% of Scrabble champions have been women and the rest have been men. There is one champion per year. Of the men, 40% had a beard.
main-q: How many men with beards have been Scrabble champion?
qa-pairs: How many champions are men?
40% of champions are men because 100 - 60 = <<100-60=40>>40.
How many champions have been men?
10 champions have been men because 25 x .4 = <<25*.4=10>>10.
How many champions have been men with beards?
4 champions have been men with beards because 10 x .4 = <<10*.4=4>>4.

context: Tom went to the store to buy fruit. Lemons cost $2, papayas cost $1, and mangos cost $4. For every 4 fruits that customers buy, the store offers a $1 discount. Tom buys 6 lemons, 4 papayas, and 2 mangos.
main-q: How much will he pay?
qa-pairs: How much will Tom pay for 6 lemons?
For 6 lemons, Tom will pay 6 * 2 = $<<6*2=12>>12.
How much will Tom pay for 3 papayas?
For 3 papayas, he will pay 3 * 1 = $<<3*1=3>>3.
How much will Tom pay for 2 mangos?
For 2 mangos, he will pay 2 * 4 = $<<2*4=8>>8.

context: Josh has soccer practice on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday from 3:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.  He has band practice on Tuesday and Thursday from 3:30 p.m. to 5:00 p.m.
main-q: From Monday to Friday, how many hours does Josh spend on extracurricular activities?
qa-pairs: How many hours does Josh spend on soccer?
Josh practices soccer 2 hours x 3 days = <<2*3=6>>6 hours.
How many hours does Josh spend on band?
He practices band 1.5 hours x 2 days = <<1.5*2=3>>3 hours.
How many hours does Josh spend on extracurricular activities?
From Monday to Friday, on extracurricular activities, Josh spends 6 + 3 = <<6+3=9>>9 hours.

context: After trick-or-treating, Brent dumped his candy on the table.  He had received 5 Kit-Kat bars, three times that amount in Hershey kisses, 8 boxes of Nerds,  and 11 lollipops.  He also had 10 Baby Ruths and half that amount in Reese Peanut butter cups.
main-q: After giving his little sister 5 lollipops, how many pieces of candy did Brent have left?
qa-pairs: How many Hershey kisses did Brent have?
He had 5 Kit-Kats and had 3 times that amount in Kisses so he had 5*3 = <<5*3=15>>15 Hershey kisses.
How many Reese Peanut Butter cups did Brent have?
He had 10 Baby Ruths and half that amount in Reese Peanut butter cups so he had 10/2 = <<10/2=5>>5 Reese Peanut Butter cups.
How many lollipops did Brent have left?
He had 11 lollipops and gave 5 to his sister so he now had 11-5 = <<11-5=6>>6 lollipops.

context: Mike is shopping at the mall. He needs to buy a shirt, a new wallet, and some food for the evening. The shirt costs a third of the value of the wallet. The wallet is $60 more than the cost of the food, on which Mike spent $30.
main-q: How much did Mike spend that day on the shopping?
qa-pairs: How much did the wallet cost?
The wallet costs $60 more than the food, so it's $30 + $60 = $<<30+60=90>>90.
How much did the shirt cost?
So the cost of the shirt is 1/3 * $90 = $<<1/3*90=30>>30.
How much did Mike spend that day on the shopping?

context: Under standard growth conditions, the bacterial strain, E.coli, has a doubling time of 20 minutes.
main-q: If 1 single bacterial cell is used to start a culture grown under standard growth conditions, how many bacterial cells will there be after the culture is grown for 4 hours?
qa-pairs: How many minutes are in 4 hours?
How many doublings have occurred after 240 minutes?
If the doubling time is 20 minutes, then after 240 minutes, the number of bacteria would have doubled 240/20=<<240/20=12>>12 times.
How many bacterial cells will there be after the culture is grown for 4 hours?

Therefore the total yards he will be able to run to within 10 seconds is 56 x 2 = <<56*2=112>>112.

context: A professional company is hiring for a new position. They have two qualified applicants. context: Gentry assembled a new 24 foot round pool in her backyard.  To fill the pool with water, she used four hoses.  Two of the hoses each deliver water at a rate of 2 gallons per minute.  The other two hoses each deliver water at a rate of 3 gallons per minute.

qa-pairs: How many cakes did Julia bake per day?
Julia baked one less than 5 cakes per day, or 5-1=<<5-1=4>>4 cakes per day.
How many cakes did Julia bake in total?
For 6 days, Julia baked 4 cakes per day, for a total of 4*6=<<4*6=24>>24 cakes.
How many cakes does Clifford eat?
Over 6 days, every other day, Clifford sneaks into Julia's house and eats one of Julia's cakes resulting in disappearance of 6/2=<<6/2=3>>3 cakes.

context: Wendy works at a chocolate factory packing chocolates.  She can package 2 dozen chocolates in 5 minutes.
main-q: How many individual chocolates can she package in 4 hours?
qa-pairs: How many 5-minute increments are in an hour?
There are 60 minutes in an hour and she packs chocolate in 5-minute increments. So that's 60/5 = <<60/5=12>>12 5 minute increments in 1 hour.
How many chocolates does she package in 5 minutes?
12 chocolates make 1 dozen and she packages 2 dozen in 5 minutes so that's 12*2 = <<12*2=24>>24 chocolates in 5 minutes.
How many individual chocolates can she package in 1 hour?
12 5 minute increments are in an hour and she packages 24 chocolates in 5 minutes so she can package 12*24 = <<12*24=288>>288 individual chocolates in 1 hour.

context: Kenny plans to mow lawns all summer, and then use the profits to buy video-games and books. He charges $15 per lawn. The video-games are $45 each. The books are $5 each. At the end of the summer he has mowed 35 lawns. There are 5 video-games he really wants, and then he will use the rest for books.
main-q: How many books can he buy?
qa-pairs: How much money does Kenny earn?
Kenny earns $525 because 35 x 15 = <<35*15=525>>525.
How much money does Kenny spend on video games?
